questions.text: Transovarial transmission is a feature of which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Transovarial transmission is a feature of Orientia tsutsugamushi which causes scrub typhus.

Transovarial transmission refers to passing on the disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod. Orientia tsutsugamushi is maintained by transovarial transmission in trombiculid mites. It is also seen in Rickettsia rickettsii, Rickettsia conorii, and Rickettsia akari.

The image below shows a trombiculid mite. 

Trench fever (option D) is caused by Bartonella quintana.

questions.text: A 36-year-old trekker presented with fever, headache, and rashes following a tick bite. He was later diagnosed to have Rocky Mountain spotted fever. Which of the following statements is false about the microbe implicated?
questions.solution:
Rocky Mountain spotted fever is caused by Rickettsia rickettsii. A cell wall is present in rickettsial organisms.

Rickettsiae are obligate intracellular, gram-negative pleomorphic coccobacilli. They are unable to grow in cell-free media and are thus cultured in yolk sacs of embryonated eggs. They are non-motile, non-capsulated organisms that contain both DNA and RNA. They reproduce by binary fission and are transmitted by arthropods like ticks and lice (except Coxiella burnetii and Bartonella henselae).

The rickettsiae are localized in endothelial cells of small blood vessels (except Ehrlichia and Anaplasma) in humans. They cause endothelial cell enlargement and degeneration, predisposing to thrombus formation. Tetracyclines, macrolides, and fluoroquinolones are effective against this group but, beta-lactams are ineffective.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding endemic murine typhus?
questions.solution:
The vector for endemic murine typhus is the rat flea, Xenopsylla cheopis.

Endemic murine typhus is cuased by Rickettsia typhi (option B) while epidemic typhus is caused by Rickettsia prowazekii. The zoonotic reservoir for R. typhi is the rat. Humans are infected when flea feces contaminate pruritic bite lesions. Transmission can also occur via inhalation of aerosols of dried feces of rickettsemic rat flea. No man-to-man transmission occurs. Patients present with fever, chills, vomiting and a maculopapular rash that is more prominent on the trunk. Diagnosis is by serology and treatment is with doxycycline.

When male guinea pigs are inoculated intraperitoneally with blood from a case of endemic typhus, they develop fever and a characteristic scrotal inflammation. The scrotum becomes enlarged and the testes cannot be pushed into the abdomen. This is known as the Neil-Mooser reaction. It is positive with Rickettsia typhi (option D) and negative with Rickettsia prowazekii. 

The image below shows the rat flea, Xenopsylla cheopis.

Related Pearl: Human diseases caused by the Rickettsia and Orientia species

questions.text: Multiple inmates at a prison are suspected to have epidemic typhus following an arthropod infestation. Which of the following vectors is implicated in the spread of this disease?
questions.solution:
Louse (image B), Pediculus humanus corporis, transmits epidemic typhus. 

Gaol fever/ Jail fever/ epidemic typhus is caused by Rickettsia prowazekii.

Related Pearl: Lice

  • There are 3 kinds of lice. They are:
    • Head lice (Pediculus capitis)
    • Body lice (Pediculus corporis)
    • Crab louse (pubic louse – Phthirus pubis).
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a pair of antennae, three pairs of legs attached to the thorax, and a segmented abdomen.
  • The stages in their life cycle are eggs (nits), larva (nymph), and the adult, which live for 30 to 50 days.
  • They are spread by direct or indirect contact.
  • They are vectors for epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, trench fever, and pediculosis.
  • Insecticidal control of lice is mainly by malathion in the form of lotion or powder.
  • There are reports of resistance to DDT and HCH.
  • Personal hygiene is of utmost importance to prevent infestation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man from Kashmir presents with fever, chills and rash for 1 week. The rash appeared on the 5th day of the fever starting from the trunk and progressing to the limbs. Epidemic typhus is suspected. Which of the following statements is incorrect about the disease?

choices.text: Brill-Zinsser disease is a recrudescent form
Rash is present on palms and soles

questions.solution:
Epidemic typhus rash spares the palms and soles. 

Epidemic typhus, caused by Rickettsia prowazekii, is transmitted by the louse Pediculus humanus corporis. There is no transovarial transmission of R. prowazekii. The disease spreads through infected louse feces deposited when the louse feeds on the human host. It is commonly seen in poor unhygienic or cold conditions.

Epidemic typhus starts with fever and chills. A characteristic rash appears on the fourth or fifth day, starting on the trunk and spreading over the limbs but sparing the face, palms, and soles. In some patients who recover from epidemic typhus, the rickettsiae may remain latent in the lymphoid tissues or organs for years. Such latent infection may, at times, be reactivated leading to recrudescent typhus (Brill-Zinsser disease).

Transovarial transmission refers to passing on the disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod. It occurs with Orientia tsutsugamushi, Rickettsia rickettsii, R. conorii and R. akari.

Note: Rash on palms and soles is typically described in Rocky Mountain spotted fever, secondary syphilis and hand, foot, and mouth disease

The image below shows the rash of epidemic typhus.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for scrub typhus?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for scrub typhus is doxycycline.

To treat scrub typhus, oral doxycycline 100 mg is given twice daily for 7–15 days. In the case of pregnant women, oral azithromycin 500 mg for 3 days may be used as doxycycline is contraindicated in pregnancy.

Scrub typhus is a rickettsial infection caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi. The vector is a trombiculid mite. Humans are infected when they are bitten by the mite larvae known as chiggers. The incubation period is 1- 3 weeks. Patients develop a characteristic eschar at the site of the mite bite, along with regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash. It can be associated with fever, headache, myalgia, meningoencephalitis, myocarditis, and pneumonia.

Serologic assays are used for diagnosis. Weil-Felix reaction is a heterophile agglutination reaction used for diagnosis, wherein the sera are tested for agglutinins to the O antigens of Proteus strains OX19, OX2, and OXK. OXK alone is agglutinated in scrub typhus.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man came with complaints of fever and a skin lesion as shown below. He gives a history of hiking in scrub forests a week prior, where he suffered an insect bite. On examination, there is regional lymphadenopathy and a maculopapular rash. Which of the following arthropods is involved in the spread of this disease?
questions.solution:
A history of contact with scrub vegetation with fever, regional lymphadenopathy, maculopapular rash, and eschar at the bite site is suggestive of scrub typhus.

Scrub typhus is caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi and transmitted by trombiculid mite. Doxycycline 100mg BD for 7-14 days is the drug of choice for treatment of scrub typhus in adults. In case of pregnant women and children, azithromycin or chloramphenicol may be preferred where doxycycline is relatively contraindicated.

questions.text: A wildlife photographer presents with a blackish lesion at the site of an insect bite from a few days back. He also gives a history of fever.  A positive Weil-Felix test with OX K agglutinins was observed. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, a history of insect bite followed by the development of a characteristic eschar at the site of the bite and a positive Weil-Felix test with OX K agglutinins suggests a diagnosis of scrub typhus.

Weil-Felix reaction is a heterophile agglutination reaction, wherein the sera are tested for agglutinins to the O antigens of certain Proteus strains OX 19, OX 2, and OX K. The basis of the test is sharing an alkali stable carbohydrate antigen by some Rickettsiae and by some strains of Proteus.

questions.text: A veterinarian presents with new-onset mitral regurgitation and fever. An echo reveals valve vegetations and blood cultures show no growth. Q fever is suspected. Which of the following statements is false regarding the organism implicated?
questions.solution:
Coxiella burnetii is the causative organism of Q fever. It is transmitted by ixodid ticks in animals; however, it is not transmitted to humans via ticks. 

Coxiella burnetii is a filterable, obligate intracellular pathogen. They are gram-negative but are better stained with Gimenez, Giemsa stains. They are heat resistant and hence survive Holder's method of pasteurization.

Q fever is a zoonosis and the primary source of human infection are infected cattle, sheep, and goats. It spreads through the inhalational route. Veterinarians are at higher risk due to increased exposure. Acute disease resembles influenza, nonbacterial (atypical) pneumonia, and hepatitis. Chronic disease presents as culture-negative bacterial endocarditis in patients with valvular heart disease.

questions.text: A patient presents with redness of the eye and foreign body sensation. On examination, there is follicular hypertrophy in the lower lids and moderately abundant exudates. Chlamydial infection is suspected. Which strains could have caused this condition?

choices.text: Serotypes A, B, Ba and C

questions.solution:
Redness, foreign body sensation with follicular hypertrophy in the lower lids and moderately abundant exudates suggests inclusion conjunctivitis which is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serotypes D to K.

Inclusion conjunctivitis is a type of acute follicular conjunctivitis caused by C. trachomatis serotypes D to K. The infection is transmitted to the eye from genitals, or contaminated swimming pools. Patients present with foreign body sensation, redness and mucopurulent discharge. On examination, there is acute follicular hypertrophy of the lower palpebral conjunctiva and fornix, non-tender pre-auricularlymphadenopathy and superficial keratitis in upper half of cornea.

C. trachomatis is a Gram-negative, obligate intracellular bacteria. It cannot produce ATP. It causes a variety of human diseases (ocular and genitourinary) and has two main biological variants: 

  •  TRIC biovar which causes trachoma inclusion conjunctivitis (TRIC biovar). This is further divided into 12 serological variants:
    • A, B, Ba, C serovars which cause blinding or endemic trachoma
    • D to K servovars which cause inclusion conjunctivitis
  •  LGV biovar (L1, L2, L3 serotypes) which causes lymphogranuloma venereum 

Related Pearl: Characteristics of Chlamydia species causing Human infections

Species Disease Natural host  Mode of Transmission to Human Number of immunological types Diagnosis Treatment
C. trachomatis Urethritis, pneumonia, conjunctivitis, lymphogranuloma, venerum
Trachoma		 Humans Sexual contacts,
Perinatal transmission		 More than 15 Inclusions in epithelial cells seen with giemsa stain or by immunofluorescence; also cell culture Tetracyclin, erythromycin
C. pneumonia Atypical pneumonia Humans Respiratory droplets 1 Serological test  Tetracyclin
C. psittaci Psittacosis (pneumonia) Birds Inhalation of dried bird feces 1 Serological test(Cell culture rarely done) Tetracyclin

questions.text: A thick, yellowish discharge is noted from the eyes of a five-day-old neonate in the step-down ward during rounds. An iodine-stained smear of the exudates is positive for large cytoplasmic inclusions as shown in the image. Which of the following is false about the organism responsible for the above condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a thick yellowish discharge from the eye showing iodine-stained inclusion bodies is suggestive of inclusion conjunctivitis caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. As chlamydia is a bacteria, it possesses both DNA and RNA.

Chlamydiae are obligate intracellular organisms that produce basophilic inclusion bodies. They are filterable like viruses. They are called energy parasites as they lack enzymes for ATP synthesis. They cannot grow on artificial media but can grow on cell lines like McCoy, HeLa, or the yolk sac of the chick embryo.

Chlamydiae occur in two forms, the elementary body and the reticulate body. The extracellular, infective form is called the elementary body. The intracellular, non-infective, growing, and replicative form is called the reticulate body. These are found inside a membrane-bound compartment called the inclusion body which can be visualized within infected epithelial cells by iodine or Giemsa stain. The cell wall of the reticulate body is fragile and pliable, leading to pleomorphism.

questions.text: A poultry worker was admitted to ICU with severe pneumonia. Bronchoalveolar lavage was done; it showed Levinthal Cole Lillie bodies.  Which of the following is the causative organism for the above condition?
questions.solution:
Pneumonia in a poultry worker with Levinthal-Cole-Lillie bodies on bronchoalveolar lavage specimens is suggestive of psittacosis.

Levinthal-Cole-Lillie bodies are inclusion bodies of Chlamydia psittaci seen in infected cells including alveolar macrophages from patients suffering from psittacosis. C. psittaci can be transmitted to humans by direct contact with infected birds or by inhalation of aerosols from avian feather dust. Psittacosis presents with fever, chills, muscular aches and pains, severe headache, hepatosplenomegaly and gastrointestinal symptoms. Severe pneumonia may develop. It is treated with tetracycline. 

Related Pearl: Inclusion bodies seen in various conditions/diseases

questions.text: A patient presented with painful swellings on both sides of the groin as shown in the image. The clinician suspects lymphogranuloma venereum. Which is the most common serovar causing the above condition?
questions.solution:
Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) is caused most commonly by Chlamydia trachomatis LGV serovar L2.

LGV is a sexually transmitted disease, characterized by suppurative inguinal adenitis.

Related Pearl: Comparison of Genital Ulcers

questions.text: What is the incubation period of lymphogranuloma venereum?
questions.solution:
The incubation period of Lymphogranuloma venereum ranges from 10-30 days.

Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1, L2, and L3 cause lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV). The most common presentation is the inguinal syndrome, which is characterized by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: Lesion scrapings from a genital ulcer show numerous polymorphs, but no bacteria. Which of the following is the most appropriate culture medium for organisms responsible for the above condition?
questions.solution:
Clinical scrapings from a genital ulcer showing polymorphs in the absence of bacteria is suggestive of chlamydial infection and the most appropriate culture medium is McCoy cells (human synovial carcinoma cell line).

C. trachomatis is a small gram-negative bacte­rium and an obligate intracellular parasite that appears as an intracytoplasmic inclusion body. The gram stain of the cervical smear would show leucocytes but no organisms. Hence, selective culture media like the McCoy cells culture is used to isolate the organism.

Option B: Thayer–Martin agar is used for isolation of Neisseria spp. 

Option C: Robertson’s cooked meat is used for the culture of anaerobes, especially Clostridia

Option D: Pleuropneumonia-like organisms (PPLO) broth is used to culture Mycoplasma spp. and Ureaplasma spp.

Note: Abnormal urethral gram stain showing >10 PMNs/1000Å~ field in women with dysuria but without coliform bacteriuria supports the diagnosis of chlamydial urethritis.

Related Pearl: Comparison of Genital Ulcers

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presented with a 3-day history of mucopurulent cervical discharge. Gram staining of the discharge revealed numerous pus cells, but no organisms. What is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of this infection?
questions.solution:
Mucopurulent cervical discharge for 3 days is suggestive of acute cervicitis. As gram stain does not show any organism, gonococcal infection is less likely. In this case, Chlamydia trachomatis is the most likely organism. For C. trachomatis, the investigation of choice is the nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT).

NAATs are the most sensitive tests to detect chlamydia. These tests also have a high specificity comparable to culture, and in contrast to culture, do not depend on viable pathogens. Therefore, NAATs are generally considered the test of choice for chlamydia and have replaced culture as the diagnostic gold standard.

Mucopurulent cervicitis is the inflammation of the columnar epithelium and subepithelium of the endocervix in women. Its commonly caused by Neiserria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis.

questions.text: Which of the following microbes is also referred to as Eaton's agent ?
questions.solution:
Eaton's agent refers to Mycoplasma pneumoniae.

Eaton was the first to isolate Mycoplasma pneumoniae. Because it was filterable, it was considered to be a virus previously.

It was formerly known as PPLO– Pleuro pneumonia-like organism.

Related Pearl: Common names of various bacteria

List of common names and scientific names of medically important bacteria:

Common name Scientific name
Klebs-Loffler bacillus Corynebacterium diphtheria
Koch week bacillus Haemophilus aegypticus
Tubercle or Koch bacillus Mycobacterium tuberculosis
Hansen’s bacillus Mycobacterium leprae
Eaton agent Mycoplasma pneumonia
Pfeiffer’s bacillus Haemophilus influenza
Friedlander’s bacillus Klebsiella pneumoniae
Glander’s Bacillus Burkholderia mallei
Whitmore Bacillus Burkholderia pseudomallei

questions.text: A 20-year-old military recruit presented with fever, sore throat, and non-productive cough which showed no improvement with beta-lactam antibiotics. X-ray showed peribronchial pneumonia with thickened bronchial markings. Primary atypical pneumonia is suspected. Which of the following statements is false regarding the organism responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of fever, non-productive cough, no improvement with beta-lactam antibiotics along with X-ray features showing peribronchial pneumonia with thickened bronchial markings is suggestive of Mycoplasma pneumonia, also known as primary atypical pneumonia or walking pneumonia.

Mycoplasmas are not obligate intracellular parasites. They are free-living bacteria devoid of cell walls. They are highly pleomorphic, with no fixed shape or size. 

Because of their plasticity, they can pass through bacterial filters and have often been mistaken for viruses. 

Mycoplasmas do not possess spores, flagella, or fimbria. Some species exhibit gliding motility. Mycoplasmas are gram-negative, but are better stained by Giemsa stain.

questions.text: Diene’s method of staining is used for which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
Diene's method is used for mycoplasma.

Mycoplasma shows a ‘fried-egg’ colony on Diene’s method of staining. The central dark bluish area represents the area of mycoplasmal down growth whereas the pale blue periphery indicates superficial growth of mycoplasma on the agar.

questions.text: Mycoplasma is inherently resistant to which of the following antibiotics?
questions.solution:
Mycoplasma is inherently resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics.

Mycoplasma lack cell wall, and therefore, are inherently resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics as these drugs act on the cell wall.
